description.text:
The part that slips in to the clips was almost 2mm wide and I'd have had to sand half of it away to get it to fit. This one simply clips off 1mm of it so that it fits nicely. I'm not sure if our MP Mini is newer and they've changed the size of the clips in later models (ours purchased December 2017) but it's definitely not as wide as the original.

author: 3duality

title: FX Impact 22 Magazine (177 and 30 also available but untested)

description.text:
*NOTE - I only have tested the 22 caliber magazine as that's the only version I have. I've made and am working on the other calibers but I can't guarantee that they will work and they may take a bit more effort to get working.

This is a slightly modded magazine that functions exactly the same as the factory magazines at around 1/50th the price. I started by drafting the original to see if it would work. I then modified it to use a spring from a retractable badge holder because I couldn't find a cheap substitute for the original spring. I also tried cutting my own back-plate out of polycarbonate because it's much harder than acrylic. I'll probably end up replacing the factory back-plates when the acrylic gets too scratched up.

I printed these in ABS, filed the follower with a round 3/16 round file then vapor smoothed them. I'm sure PLA will work but you might use a clear coat of some sort to smooth it out.

description.text:
Replacement prop adapter for E-flite Ultra Micro (UMX) airplanes. Replaces EFLU4067, this should work on any UMX airplane which uses the 180-size brushless motor. This will still break in the event of a crash, protecting the rest of the aircraft.

This is set up to run just the prop, length has been adjusted so no spinner/backplate are required.

Holes should be good to go, the 3 mounting holes may need slight enlargement - I do this by just twisting an X-acto knife around in there a couple of times.

Printer:

XYZ Da Vinci Mini w

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed with XYZ Da Vinci Mini w at 0.2mm layer height, 50% infill, +10C temperature (black PLA) and 40mm/sec retract speed. I highly recommend using a brim to ensure that this stays level and true.
Designed in eMachineShop.

Shoutout to jrebeiro for the design!

I originally wanted to add a spare 30mm fan to the top of this case. And while it is possible with a raspberry pi 3, it isn't really necessary. After doing some reading online, it doesn't seem like I could ever get the Pi hot enough to cause performance issues. So I opted to add another vent instead. The Raspberry Pi cutout sits just above and slightly off-center from the Pi's processor. I didn't want to damage the integrity of the original design, and to be honest I prefer how this looks.

Happy printing!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Printed in PLA
205 print temp
70 bed temp

There are 4 holes that run from the bottom of the case almost to the top.
I stuck in pieces of 1.75 mm filament and broke them off and then extruded extra filament into the holes and smoothed it with my fingers.
It won't create an unbreakable seal, but it will allow you to pick up the case without it falling apart.
Painted with acrylic paint.
(Not to perfect color/paint area specifications for you nit-pickers out there)

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
This is a modified case to replace the stock Case for the TBS race tracker. I wanted to make this case so i could move the antenna to the outside for better a better connection. I was also having problems with my unit freezing up and i had to let the battery die before it would shut down, so i added a switch to solve this problem.

Additional items needed

m3 bolts
mini latching push button switch
roughly 2 inch wire 12-14 guage i believe.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B075VBV4QH/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Assembly:

1) Remove the electronics from the original case.
2) De-solder the hot wire from the board.
3) Solder roughly 2 inch wire to the board in place of the original hot lead from the battery and leave the other end open for now.
4) Cut the shrink wrap from around antenna and remove,
5) Run antenna lead through top 3d printed plate through the second hole from the top right and then through original bolt hole on the upper right side of board, connect to pin on the board.
6) Pre-tin the switch blades, place into hole on the side of bottom case and start the plastic nut.
7) Solder positive lead from board and positive lead from battery to each opposing blade on the switch. this must be done inside of the case with the switch installed, so be careful not to burn yourself or the case.
8) Place board into case insuring that if fits, place cover on and install two m3 bolts to the bottom two holes
9) place the antenna support over the antenna and install the remaining 2 m3 bolts.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

No

No

Resolution:

.100-.300

Infill:

30-100%
Clean any stringing up and use a drill bit to fit bolt holes.

author: spdz

description.text: simple design do not know how it will actually turn out

This was designed in trueSpace and printed on a Form1 at lowest resolution. The center channel is constrained to 100 microns.
May be able to get down to 25-50 micron flow channel.
Will try to buff or grind optically clear side for particle counting. An arduino UNO and a sparkfun light sensor (0.1 lux) might do the trick for a simple particle counter. Could use sheath fluid to narrow the center flow even more. Might even roughen the center lumen then stretch it on the Z-axis and twist to narrow the center. This might give an interesting vortex property to the channel flow. Who knows, 3D printable Flow Cytometer?

comments.text: The Form1 is a laser polymerization platform that uses a blue laser to polymerize resin at the bottom of a resin tank. The build platform is inverted so it moves up as each layer is deposited.  There's no "filament" on this system.

author: ChiselingPixels

title: Microwave oven mica waveguide cover plate for GE JE1860G, part # WB06X10162

description.text:
Microwave ovens have a waveguide cover made from a thin sheet of mica material that allows the microwave energy to enter the oven cavity, but prevents food splashes from contaminating the waveguide.

Over time, the mica sheet breaks down and eventually needs to be replaced.
The replacement parts are available for many models, but it costs a lot less to buy a sheet of mica and cut it to fit.
Search for "microwave waveguide cover" and you'll find lots of products available.

I have a GE JE1860GB microwave oven. http://searspartsdirect.com says that the Microwave Waveguide Cover part number is WB06X10162, but is discontinued.
Amazon.com has it available for $36. Yikes!
I bought four 5.1" square "Microwave Cover Mica Wave Guide Sheet" on eBay for $1.75 from China including shipping.

I measured the waveguide cover from my microwave and created the design in Inkscape.
I used a Universal Laser Systems (ULS) PLS6.75 to cut the mica sheet.
"mica" is not in the PLS software's material database. I tried using "mat board" and it cut perfectly. It was a lucky guess.

Printer:

PLS6.75

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

It differs from other models as the inductive charger wont work with the heart rate monitor, so they have gone back to the standard 4 pin puck USB charger . Its held on with magnets & quite frankly its Pathetic for a name brand watch. It will hardly stay in place & the slightest movement on the cable will dislodge it & cut charging .

This cradle hold the watch Firmly in place on the charge pins for much more reliable charging .
A Desktop Stand is also included .

Please " Like" & post Made photos if you find this design useful

title: Eachine Camera Mount TX-02 for RC Cars

description.text:
Use this mount if you want to semi-permanently attach an Eachine TX-02 FPV camera the roof of a cheap rc car or any flat surface. You'll probably need to rotate the file 90 degrees in your slicer to make it sit flat, there should be no support needed or overhangs when printing. Have some really thin craft foam to place between the mount and the camera, since there will be a screw between them. You don't want a short to happen while you drive around a bumpy surface.
Update I have reinforced the walls, as taking hard crashes with the current mount caused the rear wall to split from the base.

I have also added a battery clip, just drill some holes and screw it on, most 1S LiPo batteries should simply fit into the opening and be held by friction. You could use these battery clips to store extra batteries on the car itself, for easy battery swapping.

Assembly Steps

1) Drill a hole proportional to your screw size on the little flap coming off the base.
2) Thread screw halfway through printed base to help stretch and add threads. Do the same to the surface of your rc car where you plan to mount the base.
3) With base mounted with one screw, drill a second hole in the middle of the base where the camera would sit.
4) Remove screw as well as the base to clean up surfaces and thread your new hole,
5) Cut a thin piece of foam, fabric, or anything that is not conductive that will fit inside the base walls and cover the head of the screw. This is to prevent the screw from causing a short due to vibrations when driving.
6) Screw down the base firmly, being careful not to crack it from over tightening.
7) Loop a small rubber band around camera lens, then through the back of the printed case and wrap around the lens from the other side. This will help keep the camera from flying off. Or you can lightly hot glue the camera into the base. LIGHTLY I say, you want this to be reversible in case the base itself cracks or warps form heat or something.

title: FLSUN3D i3 reinforced Z axis lead screw mount

description.text:
This is a reinforced z axis lead screw mount for the right side (side with stepper on it) of a FLSUN3D i3 reprap, to replace the stock mount which has the x axis hanging off the Z axis rods. The stupid original design simply uses a flat lasercut piece of acrylic which bends and eventually snapped over time, so this is an alternative with 3 screw points. The included photo is the previous version before i revised it a little before uploading here.

Included also is an SKP sketchup file, i model everything with sketchup, using an stl converter it will need to be repaired before slicing, the included stl has been fixed and is slicer ready.

wether or not its actually stronger will depend on your print settings and materials, though, i printed mine at 0.3mm with PLA and its doing fine, looking visibly more structurally sound.

description.text:
An open electronics box for the Anet A8 printer. This will bolt to the same guide holes as the mainboard. It will house the mainboard and dual mosfets. It is offset as to not interfere with the X-axis motor.

There is a small cage either side of the mainboard for cable management

This just fits in the bounds as a one-piece print for the A8.

I have made some alterations to the STL since I printed it to reflect the manual alteration I had to make.

Update: 31/12/17
I have now added the STL for the Lid that will accommodate a 120mm Fan

Update: 2/1/18
I have added an STL for a 120mm - 80mm fan mount for those who already have an 80mm fan as well as STLs for a 120mm and 80mm fan cover

I have updated the Box STL file as there was a group of faces missing from the model preventing the gap behind the mainboard from printing.

Also fixed an issue with the lids mounting holes

This will now print as desired (Thanks to Atatoth for helping with this resolution)

description.text: Are you ever forced out of a book, halfway through the page? Then when you get back to reading it, you have to skim over the entire page to find where you left off? That happens to me sometimes, as well. I designed this to fix that problem. Basically, what happens is, when you leave off at a certain line, you slide the slider to point to that line, and then you close the book on it. (Try and close the book on it as close as possible to the spine, so you don't have to worry about the slider sliding around when you're not reading the book.) Not only does it save the page you're on, but it saves the line too! You're welcome. And hey, another pre-sliced object for ya! :)

print_settings.Notes:: I would recommend 4 perimeter layers so that the brass fitting will thread into the top without any cracking. Use existing PTFE connectors (1) from the MMU upgrade.

title: Prusa MMU single feed path downgrade

description.text:
Print with 4 perimeter layers minimum! This is to avoid cracking when the PTFE connector is threaded into the part.

I designed this so that I could have a backup to the multiplexer of the MMU, specifically for being able to print a single color for replacement parts if the multiplexer got jammed beyond repair. From what I understand, this is a relatively common/uncommon problem having jams in the feedpath of the multiplexer (it definitely happened to me, twice within a week or two of assembly, the second time completely blocking one of my feed paths, maybe permanently, and partially blocking the other 3 feed paths causing problems during printing).

Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2 MMU

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm layers or lower

Infill:

20% cubic

Notes:

I would recommend 4 perimeter layers so that the brass fitting will thread into the top without any cracking. Use existing PTFE connectors (1) from the MMU upgrade.

comments.author: zbrozek

comments.text: You use one of the four Festo fittings from your multi material upgrade that went into the multiplexer. You shouldn't need to purchase any parts to use this downgrade.
comments.author: zbrozek

comments.text: I guess I'd like to leave the fittings in the MMU multiplexer until that part is truly dead. Mostly so I have fewer steps to swap in case I have to "do it live". Given that there are no size constraints for getting multiple fittings on a monoplexer, I was thinking it would be nice to use the cheap ones that are easy to buy. And since I love metal threaded parts, I was also thinking it would be lovely to have a heat set brass insert up top.

Open PCR - Body folder

Open PCR was designed by Josh Perfetto and Tito Jankowski. It is a physical kit of parts that you can purchase from their website. I downloaded the SLT files from their website (http://www.openpcr.org) and uploaded the files here. I am sharing the virtual parts and builds at Thingiverse for educational purposes. I teach a biomedical engineering lab (BME 100) at Arizona State University. The students use these files for hands-on learning of CAD in the context of a biomedical application (amplifying DNA via PCR to detect disease-linked mutations).

This is the bobcat logo made into a keychain for a buddy of mine. to make into keychain size I resized it to 50% original size, printed at .2mm layer height it turned out well. solid infill just to be sure.

description.text:
extruder body of the MK3 for the MK2 MMU

This parts make the extruder to fit with the noctua fan that is included with the future MK2.5 upgrade and the new fan nozzle from the MK3.

the origin MK3 has different hotend and pinda positions, so I designed the carriage and the base to eliminate the hotend offset and made the pinda holder clamp mechanism backwards.
the carriage and the base are thinner on the two facing surfaces when assembled.

requires the MK3-x-carriage front and back, the front (included here) is modified:
extension to trigger the endstop
small cutout at the edge for the fan (because of nozzle position explained above)

My version of the carriage back part is basically the same, I just left the cutouts of the filament sensor cable away and set a new text.

get other parts (fan nozzle, cover) from prusa website or github-page.

title: Prusa i3 MK2/MK3 Raspberry Camera Mount

description.text:
Raspberry Pi Camera mount for Prusa i3 MK3 (and modified version for MK2/MK2S).

Uses camera case designed by PrintCentral (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1646474) but instead of ball connection I use screws to connect parts. You can still point it anywhere (rotate cam up/down, left/right) but it holds better.

You need one M3 and one M4 screws (both about 18mm lenght, you should have spare if you bought a kit version of Prusa i3 MK3). No zipties needed!

To mount the holder on bed frame of MK3 you have to remove the front left screw from the bed and a spacer (spacer will go through printed camera holder). You can also make loose three neighboring screws. Some force is needed to push camera mount on the frame - spacer must be aligned with the hole in the frame.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK3

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15 - 20 %

Notes:

Recommended print settings (Prusa Slic3r):
ABS/PET (dont use PLA - it is too close to heatbed)
Perimeters: 2
Infill: 20% Cubic
0.2 layer hight
No support (there is a tolerance for bridge print to fit the frame)
Detect bridging: ON
Auto cooling: ON

Presliced GCODE for MK3 is included (ABS, 0.2 layer height).

Update 1

Cable holder inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2728660 was added. You can simply put it between knob and holder. It is also possible to rotate it a bit (about 90 degrees).

Update 2

Added looser version (if you have problems to slide it on the frame).
Added longer version.

Update 3

Added holder for Prusa i3 MK2/MK2S.
There are 2 versions to print (different print orientation). Version 2 is harder to break but you have to drill (clean) the hole for the nut after.
Other printed parts (camera case, knob, etc.) are the same as for MK3.
For mounting just make loose screws in 3 corners, lift the heatbed a little bit and slide it on the frame.

Update 4

Looser and longer version fix. (Y frame mounting part was too long).

description.text:
A 3D printable foot for the Creatbot DE and DE-Plus 3D Printer models.

The Creatbot DE and DE-Plus 3D Printers are large and also quite heavy printers (32+ kg).

The chassis is welded from steel plate and the edges on the feet can be quite sharp.
As is often the case, turning or sliding the printer aside to, for example, replace a filament spool can easily scratch the desktop or platform surface it stands on.

This printer foot can be easily printed in any material you like to even the load and make moving the printer around much easier.
With glued on felt pads, it makes moving the printer even easier.

Designed in OpenSCAD.

description.text:
A remix of the original parts to fit a radial fan from a PC heatsink/fan unit. Two diagonally opposite, 100mm centre to centre diameter holes for the fan.

Also included is a shorter funnel between the cyclone and the dust collector, to reduce the height of the completed vacuum unit. The fall angle of the funnel is the same as original so hopefully it won't impact dust collection at all.

UPDATE 2017-12-30 the STLs fit the radial fan just fine. The only things I want to fix up are to change the flanges so they don't overhang where not necessary (also reducing the amount of support material required), and changing the dust collector funnel so that it uses a standard hole-saw size for the dust collector. Right now it's ~50mm, which is kind of in between sizes (the closest holesaw size is 54mm)

Unfortunately, although the vacuum cleaner assembly itself works fine, in testing I found out that my radial fan - a 90mm radial fan from an Acer desktop PC - has a "soft-start/blockage-detection" circuit which means the power reduces as it detects increased fan load.

Although rated at 2.5A, it dials it down to 0.5A when assembled, and in some cases turns off completely. All this basically means it reduces power right when you want a vacuum cleaner to work harder :-( So if I can't hack it around to bypass that inbuilt circuit, I'm left to remix and reassemble the vac to use some powerful 120mm axial fans I have from an old Sun workstation.

remixed_from.title: Tatara A8 Steel Frame - Anet A8 Swap it - V1.00

title: Tatara A8 Steel Frame V1.1 Hayabusa - Anet A8 Swap it and more

description.text:
This description text is a draft.

important

Each single part is on a separate .DWG file you have to look at the pdf parts list to know how many of each part you have to laser cut it

TATARA A8 Steel V1.10, code name: HAYABUSA

what's new Vs 1.00???
• Redesigned Y Motor Holder •
• Redesigned Rods Locker •
• Redesigned Bed Support: 100g lighter •
• Ready for IGUS TS-04 upgrade •
• Customize for your needs

Changelog:
8 February 2018:
Correct a small measurements error on YM11 part, now last version of this part is named YM11B and replace original YM11

17 January 2018:
Added a printable part, replica of Z End Stop support for who build from scratch and not do the swapping from Anet A8.

08 January 2018:
Added variants to be used with IGUS Mini linear guide (on Z axis) Kit: TKE-04-015-1-352 (you need 2, one for each side: 1 fix and 1 floating LLZ), if you want to use smooth rods and upgrade later to the linear guides, you need also the parts TP11-xxxx and ZMT11-xxxx that you can find in the versions A8-R-xxxxx.

Custom XZ printable idlers (Parts: PP-CXZ-R-SI15, PP-CXZ-L-SI15) for this versions will be released during january 2018.

You can use other linear guides too: holes diameter is M3 spaced every 40mm, but we will not design the custom XZ chariot for all existing linear guides.

With the design of this new two variants we gained 32mm in operational length on X axis; this allows the use of dual extruder with separate nozzle covering the whole 220mm heated bed size.

1 January 2018:
V1.1 Is out
The first four variants of TATARA A8 Steel V1.10, code name: HAYABUSA have been published the 1.1.2018:
A8-R-82h7
A8-R-80H7
A8-R-82h7-KLF08
A8-R-80H7-KLF08
All this versions are for ANET A8 direct swap or for new build with 8mm rods.
•Versions with 80H7 in the name: is for people can have manufactured with high precision and the 8mm rods hole are 8mm to be cut with H7 tolerance (0 to +0.015mm).
•Version with 82h7 in the name: the rods holes are 8.2mm to be cut with a negative tolerance and can use 3d printed part RPL11 and RLZB11 to precise align the rods and lock it to avoid wobbling.
•Versions with KLF08 in the name: have 2 extra holes in Z axis top plate (part TP11-KFL08-xxxx) to screw a KLF08 bearing to lock the lead screw in Z axis.

•You can also download extra laser cut parts; LCD2004 Screen holder and Y Fix belt tensioner.
•You can also download printed Parts: need and precise align locker.

•if you have problem with your stock rods lenght go here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2746024

Other versions, to be used with igus linear guide, will be published in first week of january 2018

Special thanks to Luca Colombo for suggestions on Y Motor Holder improvement.

My self and Tommaso Collini (https://www.thingiverse.com/musta/about) we tried to implement easy solution to solve common issue we found on Anet A8 printer and most of cartesian printers. We believe Tatara frame is the best steel frame you can build.
In our design all parts are inter locked that ensure great stiffness and perfect geometry on all 3 dimensions.
What is special in our design:

•XY frame to make all build more rigid, this is a major improvement against all others cartesian (prusa design clone) Steel frame that let you push printing speed to 150-180mm/sec, 20-25mm/sec2 jerk 1200 mm/sec2 print acceleration with good quality
•We add the option to add 6 LEVEL FOOT to level the printer
Nyloc/Lock nuts compatible by design
many small improvement that make the frame incredible rigid with virtual no resonance during printing.
Damn heavy, more than 9Kg only for frame. Because we are not overseas seller's weight is not a problem but a feature:
-lower center of gravity
-weight leads to a higher inertia and therefore less high-frequency vibration

Why Steel??
Steel is the material that gives the best ratio stiffness (young's modulus) vs cost/volume.
To achieve same stiffness with other materials you need to use, at least, a sheet 3 time thicker.

To be manufactured of carbon steel (requires painting) or stainless steel.
We strongly suggest the use of a material with a minimum Young Modulus of 196 GPa ( double check it before you get your frame cut).

Is designed for 3mm thickness (clearance is 3.2mm so maybe you can also use 1/8"-> 3.175mm))

people who sell Tatara frame on internet don't give any % to the designers (us) then if you enjoy the Tatara frame ( or if you make money with it)
can be kind to TIP

All measurement are the same as Anet A8 and you have to change only the frame and maybe the screws (depend what length of screw you get on your original Anet A8).
The design will be under CC attribution share alike license 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/) as well the DWG/DXF laser cut draw. Respect the licence
The draw is done from scratch, by your humble servant.

Since then more than hundreds users swap to Tatara A8 steel and push their 3D printing quality and speed to unknow frontiers.

Many users also decide to build a 3D printer from scratch using Tarara A8 Steel Frame.

This is work in progress, if you decide to laser cut is at your own risk we don't give any guaranties.
ATTENTION: Maybe your laser cut service need to do the nesting and bridging for optimization.

please don't ask for dxf file if you need convert dwg to dxf learn how to: http://bfy.tw/Froh
please don't ask for pre nesting of different parts is not our job, learn how to: http://bfy.tw/Fwrd

REMEMBER TO "Electrical Grounding" the steel frame !!!!!!

Attention
if you use anet board with anet stock FW the Y motor go to the left and nOT to the right like in the images, if you use marlin as FW you just need invert direction of Y motors in your FW

Disclaimer: cut at your risk we don't give ANY garanties.

the TATARA logo design is NOT under CC licence and you can't use without permission

For other info, temporary read the TATARA A8 Steel V1.00:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2221391

Or go to official Tatara Steel Frame Page on
FaceBook https://www.facebook.com/tatarasteelframe/

ASK questions to Official Tatara owner Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/TataraFrameOwnerGroupOfficial/

NB: We design the Tatara frame from scratch, we start with a blank sheet and open mind trying to solve engineering problems that 3D printing presents to every designer,
we get inspired by all the errors and the work done by the community of 3D printing on the last years. Licensing our projects under CC licence share alike 4.0 is a way to give back to the community.

title: Corner extension for mini 3x3 Zhanchi to turn into a 2x2 Zhanchi

description.text:
Steps to make a 2x2 Zhanchi out of a mini 3x3 Zhanchi.

  1. Cut down all 12 edges at a 45-degree angle just like an octagonal barrel or fisher cube.

  2. Bandage your mini 3x3 Zhanchi into a fused cube by using super-glue. (If you don't know what a fused cube is, then look at Nathan Wilson's video on youtube about it)

  3. Glue all 8 extensions on each of the 8 corners

  4. Lube/Tension

  5. Solve on your "new" 3d printed Dayan 2x2!

Cleaning up

Removed the supports and drilled out the holes for the drills. Most printers print holes with a little less diameter than designed. Take care not to drill too deep or you'll end op in the interior of the print and you might even lose your smallest drill in that void :) The holes are 30 mm deep.

title: Traxxas Street Sport Rear Hubs for Ball Bearings

description.text:
Want to put 5 x 11 x 4mm ball bearings into your Traxxas Street Sport's rear hubs? You can't. They don't fit.

But you can print these and do just that!

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

PowerSpec 3D Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed with ABS plastic, and this part is very strong.

This prints on its own little raft. Just trim it off with scissors or pliers or something. It gives the support something to bite into.

You may have to file or drill out the holes if your printer prints them all wobbly-like. For some reason, Blender kept messing up the inner axle hole, so it might be a little goofy, but this part works well anyway.

Note: whatever happens, you must make sure that little pass-through hole for the axle (the support between the two bearings) is larger than the inner race of the ball bearing. Otherwise, the bearing will rub on the hub and slow you down.

description.text:
I looked around for a decent base for a stack of Spool Drawer's and wasn't a fan of what was out there. My first crack at designing my own was way too flimsy and it quickly became a leaning tower. This new version is much more stable and keeps the stack upright.

This is based around a length of M8 (8mm diameter) Threaded Rod as a spine and utilises a couple of M8 Nuts to secure everything. The base itself is in two parts allowing the rod to be secured with a nut in 2 places, keeping everything much more rigid.

Parts Required:

  • 1x M8 Threaded Rod
  • 2x M8 Nuts (base)
  • 1x M8 Nut (cap)
  • Printed Spool Centre's (to suit 8mm rod)

Assembly:

-Base-

The inner piece requires two M8 Nuts to be press fitted into the top and bottom. Then screw the threaded rod into place ensuring it does not pass beyond the bottom of the piece (top side when printing). I personally used a bit of Loctite to keep it all extra snug.

Depending on your printer, the Inner and outer pieces should be a snug fit. To attach them, push the inner piece into the outer piece until as far as it will travel. Then whilst applying some downward pressure, rotate the pieces until the nubs at the bottom of the centre piece lock into the holes inside the base.

-Spacers-

This is the fiddly bit! Print 2 of the spacers for each Spool Drawer in your stack, the small columns can be press fitted into the holes and then 2 pieces pressed together (see pictures for a demo). I personally use a dab of super glue to bind it all nice and tightly.

I also found I had enough clearance between the nuts & bolts keeping the drawers in place that I could print the Spacers and 3/4's height. You don't need one at the bottom and can use regular washers if you would prefer.

-Cap-

The cap is designed for a M8 Dome Nut, you can use a regular Nut though if you would prefer. Do not over-tighten the cap or you may struggle to spin the top drawer.

-Spool Centre's-

Use whichever Spool centre pieces you prefer - ideally ones which can be used or drilled to suit M8 thread (8mm).

I personally use these: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1842680 - Drilled out to 8mm.

Designed Wholly In FreeCAD

FreeCAD was used from start to finish to design the parts for this build.

Printed on a (heavily modified) Anet A6.
JACKSONVILLE JAGUARS

description.text:
This is a rework of the cable chain mount on the Tronxy X5S, but could be used on any core X Y cube. When receiving the new X5S release the connector block has been removed and the cables are soldered together. When Tronxy did this they made the cables too short, and a complete rewire is required. This mount has a cable management box built in to correct this issue. There is space to install a solder tag strip inside, and as you see in the photo I also used a terminal block to be used for the hot end cables to make it easy switch out.
I have also added a boom arm to keep the Bowden tube away from the Y stepper on the Tronxy plus it helps with the tube sagging and fouling with the cable chain.
You will need
M2 Screws 4 x 5mm
M3 Screws 4 x 10mm I used computer case Blanking plate screws
M3 nut and bolt 40mm
cable strain relief.

Printer:

Tronxy X5S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2

Infill:

What ever you think you need

Notes:

No supports are needed all overhangs are gradual

The mount was created in SketchUp using the original chain mount. The height was extended slightly then the box was added. the cross member inside the box lifts the tag strip away from the box base to allow soldering in situ.

title: Star Wars Rose’s Rebel Alliance Iris Ring

description.text:
My take on Rose’s Rebel Alliance iris ring from The Last Jedi. I have included materials needed here, but I also did an instructional video on how to make and assemble this:
https://youtu.be/tTRXPE5q1eA

Please note that the best way to show your appreciation and keep up to date on my latest 3D printing projects is to head over to my YouTube channel and subscribe!
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeQR9E-MPwBqEpuaIJiE4CQ

The iris mechanism is based on this design:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:140048

I felt this would scale down to a ring size much better than other iris designs. With this design I was able to make the blades much thicker and easier to handle. Assembly is still a little delicate, but the video lays out clear instructions on how to do it.

The only uncommon material needed for this build is M1 x 6mm cheese head screws. I listed my source under in the .pdf (or .xlsx) BOM under “Thing Files”, but hopefully someone can find a better source.

STL quantities to print:
Iris Blade, SW Rose Ring {QTY 6x}
Rebel Symbol Insert, SW Rose Ring {QTY 1x}
Ring Base, SW Rose Ring {QTY 1x} [see below for different sizes]
Ring Cap, SW Rose Ring {QTY 1x}
Slotted Disc, SW Rose Ring {QTY 1x}

Enjoy!

Edit:

It was requested to add more versions of the Ring Base, to fit different finger sizes. I added the following STL files:

Ring Base, SW Rose Ring, 13mm ID
Ring Base, SW Rose Ring, 15mm ID
Ring Base, SW Rose Ring, 17mm ID
Ring Base, SW Rose Ring, 19mm ID
Ring Base, SW Rose Ring, 21.6mm ID (same size as file from 12-29-17)
Ring Base, SW Rose Ring, 23mm ID
Ring Base, SW Rose Ring, 25mm ID

The "XXmm ID" refers to the inner diameter of the ring portion being XXmm in diameter. This should allow you to pick the right size Ring Base for you needs.

title: FlSun Delta strong and simple carriage (GT2 belt)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Most of the carriages available for delta's with linear rails have little posts around which the belts get looped to then lock onto themselves.

I got fed up with (1) these posts breaking off when tensioning the belts or after a few days of use and (2) trying to pre-tension the belt properly when installing and failing miserably.

It looked like https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:818954 would fit the bill. However, the belt would slide out of the slot too easily, so I decided to make my own design.

Slots fit very snugly and I use self-tapping M3 screws to attach the links to avoid having to incorporate slots for M3 nuts. Regular M3 bols (without nuts may also work).

title: Modified 5 x scale LEGO Technic Motor 870

description.text:
Here are the files for the 5 x scale LEGO Technic motors I designed to make my Giant LEGO Go-Kart radio controlled!

Files are provided as-is.

There are two versions of the motor, the shells of these two motors are the same, but the front mounting plates and motor mount plates differ.:

  • Steering motor uses a brushed style motor with planetary gearbox and potentiometer feedback via a T2.5 belt.
  • Drive motor uses a brushless SK3 motor with T5 pulley to transfer power to the Lego axles.

Motor parts used:

  • SK3 3548-700KV Brushless motor
  • 80A Brushless ESC for R/C car
  • 940D Motor with 264:1 planetary Gearbox
  • Sparkfun Monster Moto Shield
  • Bourns 6630 Series 5K Potentiometer
  • Potentiometer timing Belt 58 tooth T2.5 6mm x 145mm or RS part: 474-4990

Warning !! I tried a couple of cheap clones of the Monster Moto Shield by Sparkfun, and they were terrible! One of them had a broken channel, and the other just didn't operate as expected. I have read various warning on-lin with these clones, they heat up much more than the real deal and thus are pretty dangerous.. avoid the clones!!

Parts required to complete the electrical connections in the motors and connector plugs:

  • Stereo 1/4" jack socket RS part: 208-3849
  • Stereo 1/4" jack plug or RS part: 813-8844
  • Mono 1/4" jack socket or RS part: 205-5440
  • Mono 1/4" jack plug or RS part: 813-8835

The LEGO Antenna has a recess in the base that will take a small
Orange R610V2 receiver, however, I had issues with my receiver and so didn't use it for my tests.. see video.

The Giant LEGO Go-Kart files can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2579768

author: KASTURI143

description.text:
The provided DECORATE die for extruding butter in the Butterpig design has very small holes.
If you butter isn't VERY soft, it won't extrude very easily. I took the DECORATE die and imported it into Openscad, closed up the holes, and substituted larger ones.

Its the RED die shown in the pictures.
The Openscad preview in Thingiverse only shows the modifications to the original file, it doesn't display the entire part as it is an imported STL in Openscad. But not to worry, it works.

I posted up both the .scad file and the finished STL. If you want to design your own dies, just make sure the original Baconlicious remix decorate .scad file is in the same folder as the decorate_big.scad file is.

Have fun!!

Update

  • v2 : add ring to maintain the charger. Add support for the watch to prevent fall

About the design

I've had a Fossil Q Explorist for christmas but no stand for it. Existing models was too bulky or too tight for the wireless charger. So I made one.

Features

Hold your Fossil Q Explorist while charging.

How to assemble

Print, clip the wireless charger in the hole, put your watch on the top.

Limits

It was not made to hold real T-Rex fossil.

author: Solainus

description.text:
A simple upright relay model used with arduino. It came from a need to fix it in one place and the model does not have holes to use spacer. I used abs, I printed with 30% without support.

description.text:
I was using the original version of this parts cooler and it was working very well.

I modified my Geeetech printer by replacing the hotend with a Microswiss all-metal one. The problem is, the Microswiss is almost 10mm shorter than the stock hotend. This cooler no longer worked.

I created a new parts cooler that was based on the original. I started from scratch, but took a lot of measurements from the original, which is why I linked it. You can see my nozzle is not as elegant as the original, but it works.

print_settings.Notes:: The mount holes for the fan cover should be drilled for appropriate self tapping screws.

description.text:
This is a dual extruder bracket and fan cover for a Tevo Tornado, based on the Tarantula duel hot end.
I mounted two Tarantula extruder motors at the top of the frame using their own brackets, removing the Titan stock extruder from the Z frame to save a lot of weight.
The firmware needs appropriate tweaks but I have now been running this for a few months and the print quality is awesome.
31/12/17 I thought I would add a bit more detail and a couple of pictures.

I would insulate the sides of the fan cover with Kapton tape at least as they are quite close to the hot end and may warp at temperatures above about 240 deg,

The mod is based on the Tevo tarantula dual extruder upgrade which can be found here :- https://tevo3dprinterstore.com/collections/tarantula-spare-parts/products/tevo-tarantula-dual-extruder-upgrade-full-kit-dual-extruder-cooling-fan-with-two-nema-step-motor

However the Tarantula has a 12V board compared to the 24V on the Tornado, so the heating elements will need to be changed, Example can be found here :- https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B06XPDT2T6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The firmware will need to be altered for the setup, I have uploaded the firmware here :- https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1iaJfqGSp5Q7OX_au6vGL6Mc452soXLKp?usp=sharing

However you will need to be sure it works for you, I have set the steps per mm on the extruders to 228 as this gives me the correct flow. The offsets will need to be measured between the extruder nozzle tips carefully for your setup, I would suggest using some tape on the bed and marking the nozzle positions both X and Y. Mine are X= 17.97 mm and Y = 0.48 mm, for adjusting the nozzle height Z alignment I would recommend getting the primary one spot on and levelled then lowering the head against a steel plate and adjusting the other nozzle to it so that they are identical heights.
I obviously cannot be responsible for any anomaly so installation would be entirely at your risk, but this setup works for me.

Tevo Tornado

I had foot long LED strips, which is way too long for the Ender's X-axis, so i designed the shroud with two places to run the strip, and just fold it over carefully on the end.

Overall the design works well. It lights very well and the effect of two strips for the price of one is a plus, however not everyone has these long strips, so I created an adapted version of the same mount for smaller strips. There are two versions of the single strip mounts, the 90 degree, and 45 degree. These versions just change how the LED's shine on the print.

I have some scrap magnets, taken from microwave magnets.
I did the drawing and 3D printing of a holder with magnet inside.
The exterior of the magnet is about 63mm and the inside is 20mm.
There were 36 hexagonal holes, 4.3mm and 5mm deep.

See my others projects on:

After printing, I gave a steam bath of acetone, inserted the magnet into the core, put a little acetone in the magnet and put the lid, which was welded

See more printed things https://www.youtube.com/allage

subscribe to my youtube channel and see more printed things
https://www.youtube.com/allage

description.text:
This is my first design and first time printing, I'm very happy with the way it came out.

I needed a knife rack that would fill the space in the drawer next to my current rack and hold the extra and odd sized knives that didn't fit in the first rack. The design is my own, while there were other interesting designs I wanted something that would support odd shaped blades and be sturdy enough to hold the other rack together.

This could easily be modified to support more knives or to be a different size.

The model is set up to print upside down, so make sure the bed is clean before you start. The bottom of the holder is printed last and my printer didn't have any problems bridging the 3 mm gap between the slots.

author: overbye

description.text: Hoffe es gefällt

This is a modular design. Print the parts for 1 bay or 20!
There are specific components for left, right, and middle bays. Printed in PLA. The components are "keyed" to make alignment foolproof. Most pieces will require glue. I used CA/superglue, but I think I'll use hot glue in the future. Resolution and speed are not critical. This isn't an uber realistic design, so even draft quality would probably print nicely. I printed at .15 height, 60mm/s, 10% infill, from PLA, sliced with CURA.

NOTE The second floor has an overhang. Flip it over in your slicer so you don't have to use supports.

This isn't a full depth garage, more of a facia, at about 4 inches deep. Fits really well into tight track layouts or against a back wall.

Although I envisioned this design, I didn't create the STLs. My friend Peter designed them in his CAD program. We designed the balcony and the roof billboard to accommodate Geezer's printable manufacturer's banners located here: http://slotcarillustrated.com/portal/forums/showthread.php?t=29566

Post print: I ran a file around the edges to square up everything for a nice flush fit.

Maker Select Plus

10% - 15% not critical

print_settings.Notes:: In order to get the best results without using support, set the printer to print external primeters first and infill first.  Make sure your layer fan is turned on and slow down the print speed.  A slow print speed is essential for printing the inner side of the flange with minimum defects.  Any defects in the inner surfaces are not important and can be cleaned up after printing.

title: Joy Stick Handle for Power Chair

description.text:
Update 1/3/18 rotated the model so it is on the bed in the print position.

A friend lost the control handle for his motorized power chair and inadvertently created an opportunity for a rescue by a 3D printer. The design here was a first-cut that was sketched on a napkin, but it seems to work well enough that I probably won't refine it. I intended to print it in ABS, but the PLA version I printed seems adequate.

See the photos for the original part and the controller it attaches to. I'll add a photo of the printed replacement later.

The knob mounts on a 20 mm long shaft that is 6.5 mm or 1/4" in diameter, with a 11.5 mm circular stop below.

The part has a thin internal Brim built into it that has to be removed prior to use.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used 3 perimeters, a 0.4 mm nozzle and 0.3 mm layer height.

Infill:

I used 20% Hex

Notes:

In order to get the best results without using support, set the printer to print external primeters first and infill first. Make sure your layer fan is turned on and slow down the print speed. A slow print speed is essential for printing the inner side of the flange with minimum defects. Any defects in the inner surfaces are not important and can be cleaned up after printing.

I needed to mount 6 - 120mm fans side by side on the front of the mining rig I built. I could not find any brackets that would hold the fans and then allow me to screw them to the face of the rig. I made these flush mount brackets. 1 set (top and bottom) will hold 2 fans together side by side. Photo coming with the brackets in use.

Note:
I would print them more than 50% infill. Reason for it is these were 20% and as you can see the screw heads crushed the surface a bit.

Also someone made a single: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2756758

comments.text: Thanks this is perfect for what i need. also love your rig simple and clean just wondering how you have your gpu's secured on there sides
comments.author: SkItz_Goon

comments.text: I have a crossbar about 4 inches back from the fans. This is to allow the airflow around the sides of the cards better. Used self-tapping screws on the crossbar. The whole thing is grounded to the motherboard. I have the mobo on wood but made a wire with 2 ends on it that I crimped into a flat connector. Then put that under one of the mounting points and tested it with a multimeter. You have to ground this because it will short out over time. I mention it because the crossbar needs to be part of the ground loop as well.

This was a fun engineering project to make a very small pulse motor. I included three configurations but it should be noted that configuration three was the one that worked.

You can watch the video of this build here: https://youtu.be/eSzVXSYhLmc

Watch the motor throttling in action here: https://youtu.be/QGNeUsbtkv0

The configuration that worked as you'll see in the video is the third one with the reed relay mounted at an angle.

I used magnets that are 6mm in diameter and 3mm thick. The parts were printed with Autodesk Magenta resin. They were printed on a Draken DLP 3D Printer.

This is a clamp-on guide for cutting 2-inch PVC pipe (should work for ABS as well). It will help you to make a straight cut with a hand-saw without having to use a miter box.  
To use, slide onto the pipe and then clamp on the thinner part of the ring. Clamping is not strictly necessary. Then slide the saw right against the edge of the ring.   
If you need to cut a different pipe size, see the Instructions tab.  
Prints in 1hr at 0.3mm layerheight with no support. Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360.

I printed this on a Replicator2 at low quality (0.3mm layer height), with no support. The cutting surface is oriented upwards to keep it flat, if you put it on the build plate it will be somewhat warped. To print for another pipe size, you can just scale the model. Measure the outer diameter (OD) of your pipe in mm, and use the following formula:
scale_value = (OD + 0.6) / 61
(multiply by 100 if you need a percentage) If you don't have calipers to measure, you can look up standard pipe sizes here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nominal_Pipe_Size

Engrave a design in a printable plaque with this Customizer. Design a plaque, draw a path to cut in it, and design a virtual router bit to do the cutting. (The bit is designed by rotating a cross section, just like my chalice lathe.) Lag Warning! This thing makes extensive use of the hull() command to compute the shape of the path cut between successive points. The Thingiverse Customizer docs discourage use of this command just because it is pretty slow. So, be advised it may take a very long time for the Customizer preview to update after each change. I welcome tips from any OpenSCAD pros on how to do this more efficiently.

title: M&P; 15 AR style front shield and pistol grip

description.text:
A remix of some other front grips and shields for an M&P15 style AR 15, I split the shields so they would print better on my machine. If you print the combination pistol grip and front shield, you will just need one of the front grips. These were about 1mm too long and needed to be trimmed on the forward end to fit my rifle... you may or may not find this to be the case for your use.... also, the pistol grip is a remix of another great job I found here on Thingiverse... I removed the side rails and sunk it into the front shield because the rails were too loose... the original was very well done and I basically just chopped the rails off... so some sanding and filing may be needed to clean things up...should not be more than most prints need... but I am not done printing it yet... I will update if it turns out too bad..thanks

12/31/2017...
I finished my print... fits well... not much file work needed...I did have to shorten the muzzle end by a mm or so... just as I did for the other half

author: lokilaufeysen

description.text:
Sensor:
The RCWL-0516 Microwave Radar Sensor can detect intruders at distances of 5 meters or more. When activated a signal is sent via the ESP32 WiFi to a local server where it can be further analyzed if required.

Test Units:
Included are three enclosures for testing using two different LiPo battery. The first uses a $2 creative 680mAh LiPo battery (54x35x4.5mm) as I have several new from an old project, and the second/third enclosures employs an inexpensive Turnigy 2000mAh LiPo battery (50x35x10mm) costing 3$.

The small battery should easily last 1 week and the larger 3 weeks as the average standby current is < 3mA. The smallest enclosure uses a small ESP32 module with micro USB connector for charging the battery allowing both boards to be mounted side by side greatly reducing the enclosures size.

The size of the sensor enclosure is pretty much determined by the capacity of the battery powering them, it therefore makes more sense to permanently connect units that are located close to mains sockets using an inexpensive usb/phone charger. In an ideal world a small high capacity 4 volt battery could power the sensor for six months...
...

Powering the device from a 4.2 volt 2000mAh Battery:
The RCWL-0516 is powered directly from the battery, the ESP32 is powered from the same source via a small diode (to drop the voltage to approximately 3.5 volts).

The ESP can safely operate up to 3.6 volts however this simple arrangement will ensure the supply never exceeds 3.5 volts (4.2 - 0.7 = ~3.5). In reality you could charge the LiPo battery to 4.0 volts to reduce the voltage on the ESP to 3.3 volts...

The small PCB containing the ESP32 module also includes a micro usb connector to allow for recharging...
...

Added enclosure for a sensor based on one and two 18650 3.2 volt LiFeP04 batteries. The two circuit boards slide into groves (one on each end to allow a little separation)... stl files are last in the list...
...

RCWL-0516's: 15/01/2018 (last edited: 07/0/2018)...
The range of detection was excellent, especially considering it was powered at 3.0 volts (and not the recommended 4 volt as per datasheet). I note there was no noticeable drop off in performance in several days of testing (not bad for a 35¢ device)...
...

Powering both devices from a single supply/source: options

  • Two different batteries (LiPo " 4.2 volt for RCWL-0516, LiFePO4 3.2 volt for ESP32)...
  • LDO (drop voltage from LiPo 4.2 volts to 3.3 volts for ESP32)...
  • Buck Converter (boost voltage from LiFePO4 to 4.0 volts to power the RCWL-0516)...
  • Use 1 or 2 diodes from LiPo 4.2 volt to supply the ESP32 (~3.6/~3.0)

The diode solution is current and type dependent and can be problematic, still I will test it regardless...

The LDO is the next best (lowest extra cost) but there's a 20% reduction in efficiency as the LDO uses current to maintain the voltage resulting in reduced battery life...

The two different batteries scenario is added cost but otherwise perfect.

The buck option is also costly in current consumption as well as the extra cost and hassle...
...

LiFeP04's arrive: 02/02/2018

The first LiFeP04 batteries arrived several days ago (4 x 1500mAh) the second batch (2 x 1800mAh with build in protection) arrived yesterday so I set to work experimenting.

While the nominal voltage for PoFePo4 batteries is 3.2V, they can be charged up to 4.2 volts maximum. According to the experts, at 4.3 volts the electrolytic will break down and the battery will eventually fail.

Note 1: Your battery charger should charge to 3.6 volts maximum to prevent killing your 3.3 volt devices (devices used in this design will operate at 3.6).

Note 2: I tested three different chargers and the resultant charge voltages were; 3.6, 4.0 and 4.2 volts so best make sure your charger doesn't exceed 3.6 volts otherwise you may kill your microprocessor or other devices...

Will be moving all parts relating to 3.2 volt to another project

comments.text: Filtering is not required... just ensure you have a decent reservoir cap across the ESP supply pins, the value of which is determined by the quality of the supply. In most case a 47uF 16 volts cap will suffice but with weak supply a 220uF cap may be required... If you are still having issues add another 47uF cap on the sensors supply pins...

description.text:
This is a work-in-progress. It was modeled very quickly, for my own personal need, and is not "production" quality. The assembly, in particular, is a little fiddly. You will require a mallet and a short dowel to push the individual coloured pieces into the base. You will also require an adhesive to adhere the front-most pieces of the mushroom-cap to the base. An emery board will also be useful, to smooth out edges on the blocks. You will require the following pieces to complete the mushroom:

  • 1 x base_black.stl (black)
  • 1 x face_white.stl (white)
  • 1 x cap_white.stl (white)
  • 1 x cap_red.stl (red)
  • 6 x 2x1.stl (white)
  • 6 x 3x1.stl (white)
  • 2 x 5x1.stl (white)
  • 10 x 2x1.stl (red)
  • 1 x 4x1.stl (red)

Use the image with grid, in the gallery, as a reference for placement of the pieces.

Printer:

AnyCubic i3 Mega

Rafts:

title: Watercooling reservoir
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Needed to upgrade watercooling setup for couple of my PCs and thought that why not design my own reservoir? So this is the first design and I printed couple of these using PETG and Filaflex for gaskets.

Designed for immersive pump, Im using Eheim Compact 600. Has 2 16mm holes for passthrough tube adapters and 1 12mm for pump wire passthrough (see pics).

Models include gaskets which I printed using Filaflex.

After fixing the leaks and observing two reservoirs running on my bathroom for a couple of weeks, I installed the to 2 PC's. Still running fine after a couple of months. Just need to add water twice a month or so, seems evaporation is happening. Probably the top lid isn't that tight...

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.3mm

Infill:

20%-100%

Notes:

Problems: as 3D printed parts aren't that solid, I had some small leaks here and there, mostly on the seams. With leaks I mean a very slow trickling, kind like sweating. So here are a couple of tips for getting watertight parts:

  • randomize seam position. I had seam on one corner -> leak
  • use multiple perimeters, at least 3
  • over-extrude a bit so less small gaps between perimeters. I bumped mine to 105% in Slic3r
  • set perimeter/infill overlap to higher number, like 30% or more
  • use larger nozzle. Bigger paths, less gaps. Second reservoir I printed with 0.8mm nozzle and it leaked only at the seam
  • vase-mode with large nozzle. Won't work with this model (at least haven't tried)

Post-processing for fixing leaks
  • use soldering iron to melt the problematic parts. Careful not to mess the parts too bad. In my experience melting only to top most layers is enough.
  • glue. I tried hot glue, but not sure if it's a good long term solution. Some kind of silicone might work better.
OpenSCAD. Source here: https://github.com/spegelius/3DModels/tree/master/Watercooling

title: Monoprice Mini Delta E3D V6 Clone Mount

description.text:
I wanted to change the factory hot end to an all metal E3D V6 style with minimal changes to the overall printer. Other designs either replace the entire effector, or are really large. This design is a direct screw in replacement for the factory Monoprice hot end, and is compatible with both the Monoprice or E3D style heat blocks. It even uses the factory fan and cooling duct. The screws used to hold the factory hot end to the effector plate are reused, and the only "special" hardware required are two #4-20 x 3/4" rolling thread screws (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GDXW3OE/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1) to fasten the collar around the hot end.

Since the factory heat block can be reused, all of the original wiring can be reused as well. There is an opening in the top large enough for the heating element connector to fit through, so installation is a snap.

This design has been tested and I am currently printing with it. Since none of the factory wiring is changed, this mod can be made, and reverted in case an RMA for the printer is required without affecting the warranty.

EDIT
I wasn't thrilled with the heat break cooling on some of the longer prints I made, so I decided to tweak some things. Hopefully, the new passages will force more air through the heat break, as well as put the part cooling duct closer to the nozzle.

I also countersunk the screw holes on the locking collar, so they should sit more flush.

Printer:

Monprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50% (for strength)

Notes:

Print using a high temperature filament such as ABS, PETG, or Nylon. Infill percentage can be anywhere from 50-100 percent, but use more wall thickness if lower infill will be used.

If using the E3D style heat block, ensure you wrap the block in insulation, as the block is larger than the factory one, and is very close to the mount. The block does not touch, but the insulation will reduce radiated heat from the block to any surrounding plastic parts.

print_settings.Notes::
revised the hood and top display panel. The Adafruit 2.2-inch TFT display now fits in like a glove. (If you are not using electronics, then go with the original un-remixed part and screen.) The panel plate is glued in place to keep the panel from coming loose and that way you don't have to put glue on your nice display electronics. This isn't needed if you are going for pure prop/cosplay use. The hood plugs are designed to fit tight on the sides of the frame, but loose on the hood so it opens nicely. When I get to the electronics part of this adventure I will design a new hood swivel that's hollow so wires can pass thru it, and thru the frame, to be routed wherever. I printed the hood on its side and used supports, however if you don't care what the inside of the hood looks like you can print without supports. It just looks a little wild and wooly on the inside top when you forgo supports.
  • all dimensions are unchanged so the un-remixed parts will fit. Mix and match as you see fit.

description.text:
My 1st attempt to construct this was from individually printed parts and then glued together. When I got it all together I found that it was out of tru (ie, not rectangular). So I took all the frame parts into Tinkercad and put them together, then merged the parts into one form. Then I printed that.

  • NOTE: I printed everything in this post. If you choose to print this, it will all print and it will all fit together. Enjoy.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Supports are only needed along the rear very bottom of the frame, where the back door hinges, and along the top for the tall side of the hood housing. The rest of the frame lies flush on the print surface. Print time was about 10 hrs at medium quality. The hood, doors and internal parts all fit with no modification from the original. The frame is just in one piece now and guaranteed to be true.

1/2/2018 - revised the frame and side panels. Side panels now have snap fits. They just pop on and lock into place. I printed these on their sides, so supports are needed. NOTE - the texturing on the side of the side panels gets in the way of a good solid sticking to the build plate. I printed mine dropped 0.5 mm into the build surface, so the backs of my side panels are smooth, not textured. Unless you are looking for it, you can't tell. You may choose to print using other orientations and rafts and such. I have no idea how that will work out.

  • revised the hood and top display panel. The Adafruit 2.2-inch TFT display now fits in like a glove. (If you are not using electronics, then go with the original un-remixed part and screen.) The panel plate is glued in place to keep the panel from coming loose and that way you don't have to put glue on your nice display electronics. This isn't needed if you are going for pure prop/cosplay use. The hood plugs are designed to fit tight on the sides of the frame, but loose on the hood so it opens nicely. When I get to the electronics part of this adventure I will design a new hood swivel that's hollow so wires can pass thru it, and thru the frame, to be routed wherever. I printed the hood on its side and used supports, however if you don't care what the inside of the hood looks like you can print without supports. It just looks a little wild and wooly on the inside top when you forgo supports.

description.text:
I was looking to set up a game of Capture the Flag with the kids, and needed to make up some flags. Instead of just tying a piece of fabric to a pole, I made up these brackets. Print out the pair (the top one is capped so it stays at the top of the pipe), slide them on to a piece of 3/4 PVC pipe (they are made to friction fit), feed a corner of any piece of fabric (I used bandannas) through to loop on each piece, knot it and voila! easy flag...
I also have a version that is a little tighter but has a split, so it should open up a little to slide easier and accommodate minute differences in pipe diameter, or perhaps fit on painted pipe if you so desire.
Now get out there and have some fun!

description.text:
I've printed several 150% and 200% bullet bills and thought, man, it would be awesome to use the extra space at the bottom of the cap for something. Then the idea of turning it into a piggy bank came to me. I used tinkercad and modified the Red Insert part of the model to include a slot that would fit coins, even at 100%. This is modified to the Bullet Bill/Banzai Bill by Martin Moore from myminyfactory.

The slot is partly hidden by the bottom teeth.

I may try to shorten up the model a little bit for more room and less print time.

Printer:

Tevo Tornado

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.3

Infill:

5%

Notes:

I print at 60mm/s with 5% infill at a resolution of 0.2 or 0.3. I've printed this successfully on the Tevo Tornado and Qidi Tech I at 100%,150%, and 200%. I haven't had a need for rafts or supports.

comments.text: You should print an elongated body like the one I made here - more coins to store.

comments.text: I'll have to give that a try at some point. More space is usually a good thing. I do plan on trying your fixed teeth and pupils though. The bottom teeth are always a pain to get in unless I shave a little plastic off.

description.text:
I wanted to model out the shelving we used in our warehouse for a project. It's simple, and mostly to scale. Each millimeter is equivalent to an inch. The horizontal file is a 10 foot section, but can easily be scaled in your slicer to whatever size you need. I'm printing these out and gluing them together, so I will upload the files for those tools when I make sure they work.

This style shelving has keyholes facing outwards on the vertical pieces and flanges with pins on the horizontal pieces. I skipped modeling the flanges on the horizontal pieces to keep it simple. Besides, that wouldn't physically work when printed at this scale. You can use these models to help plan out warehouse shelving if you need to do that. Trust me, a little computer work is a lot easier than moving these things.

description.text:
(please sorry for my english, feel free to correct me)
Ikea is a wonderful world. 90% of the product's offered are good quality and well thinked.
unfortunately for 10% of them, it was a bad day for the engineers : when you buy an Ikea Kitchen, and a dish washer which is another brand name (because Ikea dish washers are really expensive for what they do), you have to buy BEHJÄLPLIG Rail Set. And this one is really bad, because even if you fix it exactly what the specification sheet says, you will end with a top broken part. In my country, you can't find it anymore, Ikea decided to not sell it, because of the complains and the weakness of the parts. As I couldn't find here free STL, I designed it.

You will notice that the STL is really ugly, because it was designed with 3 2D Scans and SVG of the original piece, and they did not have exactly the same dimensions between them, but it's working.

I'm also too ashamed to put scad file, also you don't need it.

you have 3 parts :

One is a for the bottom fixation, because the door I used for my dish washer was maybe to large, so I needed it.

The second is also for the bottom fixation, it's a cap for the joint between the 2 original IKEA plastic parts. Because it happened to me that the door fell down on the ground.

The last one is the part you always break :) it's the part you have to plug in the rail's door

40

Used Cura Software, 80mm/s printing, 120mm/s traveling
I first made 2D scans with the original part, see the 3 SVG. Then convert into inkscape 0.92 to .scad file. SVG are not exact dimensions so this is why the result is ugly :)
